title: Arduino Sound & Timing - Quiz
description: Test your knowledge of tone(), noTone(), millis(), for loop, and volatile in Arduino programming.

questions.question: What does the tone() function do in Arduino?
options: Generates a square wave on a pin to produce sound
Measures sound frequency from a microphone
Stops sound output from a buzzer
questions.explanation: tone() generates a square wave signal on a specified pin to drive a buzzer or speaker.

questions.question: Which function is used to stop a sound started by tone()?
questions.explanation: noTone() stops any sound currently being played on a pin by tone().

questions.question: What does millis() return?
options: Time in seconds since the last delay() call
Milliseconds since the board was powered on
questions.explanation: millis() returns the number of milliseconds since the Arduino started running.

questions.question: Why is millis() preferred over delay() in some cases?
options: It makes the code run slower
It allows multitasking without stopping the program
questions.explanation: Unlike delay(), millis() allows you to keep the program running while tracking time.

questions.question: Which of the following is the correct structure of a for loop?
questions.explanation: A for loop follows the structure: for(initialization; condition; increment).

questions.question: What is the purpose of the volatile keyword?
options: To tell the compiler that a variable may change unexpectedly
questions.explanation: volatile tells the compiler not to optimize a variable because it may change unpredictably (e.g., in an interrupt).

questions.question: What happens if you forget to use volatile on a variable used inside an interrupt?
options: The variable may not update correctly, causing bugs
questions.explanation: Without volatile, the compiler may optimize the variable and ignore changes made inside an interrupt.

questions.question: Which of the following correctly plays a sound at 500Hz for 1 second?
questions.explanation: tone(pin, frequency, duration) is the correct format.

questions.question: In the provided tryThisCode, what does playMelody() do?
options: Loops through multiple tones and plays them one by one
questions.explanation: playMelody() runs a for loop to iterate through an array of frequencies and plays them in sequence.

questions.question: What is the role of noTone(BUZZER_PIN) inside playMelody()?
questions.explanation: noTone() briefly stops sound to act as a delay between musical notes.
